items.title: Norwegian biathlete dies at 27 during Olympic training camp in Italy
items.summary_auto: Norwegian biathlon Olympic hopeful Sivert Guttorm Bakken has died suddenly. He was 27.

items.title: This unique forest is being considered for protection, but Quebec has already approved roadwork
items.summary_auto: Tensions are mounting in Quebec’s Mauricie region as citizens, environmental groups and scientists push back against provincially approved forestry roadwork in a rare old-growth forest near Sainte-Thècle.

items.title: Immersive show illuminates 800-year-old cathedral in Brussels
items.summary_auto: The Cathedral of Saint Michael and Saint Gudula in Belgium's capital is celebrating its 800th anniversary in 2026. The festivities include a one-hour immersive light show that combines 360-degree video mapping and live music.

items.title: Canada, led by 6 returning players, looking to rebound off world junior flops
items.summary_auto: Gavin McKenna's first experience at the world junior hockey championship ended in bitter heartbreak nearly a year ago. The 18-year-old Canadian forward and five fellow returnees from the Ottawa horror show are looking to make amends.

items.title: Actor-comedian Russell Brand charged with two more sex offences, according to U.K. police
items.summary_auto: New charges against British comedian and actor Russell Brand follow five initial ones made in April involving four women.

items.title: All the Cancon songs in Heated Rivalry
items.summary_auto: The best moments on the new show heating up the internet are soundtracked by Canadian tunes by Feist, Wolf Parade, Lou Phelps, Phillipe B and more.

items.title: Saskatoon police shoot man during standoff triggered by mental health call
items.summary_auto: The province's Serious Incident Response Team has provided some information about how Saskatoon police shot a 25-year-old man while responding to a mental health call.

items.title: CUSMA is up for review in 2026, and here's what Trump might want
items.summary_auto: A mandatory review of the Canada-U.S.-Mexico-Agreement on trade kicks into high gear next year as U.S. President Donald Trump continues his campaign to realign global trade and poach key industries from the country's closest neighbours.

items.title: Canadian economy shrank by 0.3% in October, the biggest slump in almost 3 years
items.summary_auto: The drop was largely due to contraction in the goods and services sectors. Analysts had predicted that growth would dip by 0.2 per cent ahead of the release.

items.title: Parents of stillborn baby channel grief into advocacy for health system improvements
items.summary_auto: Laura and Nick Bordignon were devastated when they mistakenly received an autopsy invoice addressed to their stillborn daughter. Since then, they have met with health officials to push for administrative changes, to make sure their grief wasn't in vain.

items.title: Can Jasper’s new breeding centre save caribou from local extinction?
items.summary_auto: For decades, caribou in Jasper National Park have been declining, and experts warned that without intervention, they would become locally extinct. In response, Parks Canada invested $40 million in the Caribou Conservation Breeding Centre, the first facility of its kind in North America.

items.title: What do kids actually write to Santa about? The things they can’t tell anyone else
items.summary_auto: The website emailsanta.com receives millions of letters from children (and adults) from across the world, all addressed to Santa Claus. While many take the opportunity to ask Santa for gifts, lots of children also write looking for comfort.

items.title: Trucking companies face interprovincial issues amid national conversation on alleviating barriers
items.summary_auto: The Manitoba Trucking Association says businesses in the industry continue to grapple with interprovincial issues every day, despite a national conversation on alleviating barriers in light of American tariffs. One company on the Manitoba-Saskatchewan border says navigating two sets of provincial rules adds administrative burdens.

items.title: Manitoba First Nation sues former chief, alleging 'kickbacks,' diversion of funds and other 'corrupt practices'
items.summary_auto: Peguis First Nation is suing former chief Glenn Hudson over allegations he failed to act in the best interest of the band and financially benefitted from breaches of duty — including claims that he enriched himself, his family and supporters.

items.title: Losing ground: Northern communities seek solutions for threatened cemeteries
items.summary_auto: More than half the cemetery in Fort McPherson, N.W.T., could be lost to erosion in 30 years. Communities in the Yukon and Nunavut share what they've learned from dealing with similar challenges.

items.title: In times of drought, why are residential consumers ‘targeted’ with conservation measures?
items.summary_auto: As the worst drought in decades dragged on through the summer of 2025, some Nova Scotians who use municipal water supplies were asked and then ordered to conserve water. This generated resentment and resistance over a perceived double standard between residential and commercial users.

items.title: Bitter feud ensues after landlord's failed attempt to raise tenants' rent 65%
items.summary_auto: A New Brunswick tenant and his landlord have been in a bitter year-long dispute that involves a 65 per cent rent increase, a failed eviction attempt, and claims that the rental unit, a bungalow, is needed to house the owner's aging mother-in-law.

items.title: Russian air attacks pound Ukraine, killing 3 and knocking out power in most regions
items.summary_auto: Russia fired more than 650 drones and three dozen missiles at Ukraine in a large-scale attack that began during the night and stretched into daylight hours Tuesday, officials said. At least three people were killed, including a four-year-old child.

items.title: As tiny tots sing, tap and play in music class, experts say it boosts their brain development
items.summary_auto: Music classes for the very youngest children can set them up to one day play an instrument, but experts say the classes can also bring broader cognitive benefits: firing up areas of their developing brains linked to attention, memory and language development.

items.title: War museum acquires rare WW II-era knife after it winds up at community tool library
items.summary_auto: A parachute release knife of the type used by soldiers in the Second World War has found a new home at the Canadian War Museum, after being found among other donations to the Ottawa Tool Library.

items.title: Holidays got you burnt out? Carve out moments of solitude, say experts
items.summary_auto: Between office parties, family gatherings and plans with friends, there can be lots of socializing crammed into the final weeks of the calendar. But experts say finding pockets of solitude can offer a reprieve.

items.title: For decades, Canada's military had no combat uniforms designed for women. That's about to change
items.summary_auto: More than 30 years after Canada's military allowed women to serve in combat roles, it's now specifically designing uniforms and body armour systems to fit their bodies.

items.title: I was in charge of Christmas magic for my kids. Now they're grown and things are changing
items.summary_auto: At first, Jennifer McGuire hated how her cherished Christmas traditions began falling by the wayside when her sons became adults. Now she’s learning to love some new twists on old rituals.

items.title: Giving a voice to youth is a priority for Nunavut’s new suicide prevention minister
items.summary_auto: Janet Pitsiulaaq Brewster has spent two decades working in health care in Nunavut, and she's focused much of her career on pushing for more action on suicide prevention. Now as the minister of that portfolio, she has new powers to try to spur that change, and she wants to focus on youth.

items.title: Is this Hamilton's most festive house?
items.summary_auto: On Dunsmure Road, you'll find a house that looks like it’s made of gingerbread, with a yard covered in 50 festive blow-up decorations. Neighbours come to see it, and some even chip in to help pay the electricity bills.

items.title: This year's flu is packing a punch. How hospitals are trying to deal with surging cases
items.summary_auto: Flu cases across Canada are on the rise and may push hospitals to their limits over the holidays and into the new year, leading health officials in regions across the country to warn people not to visit emergency rooms unless it's absolutely necessary.

items.title: New autism service dogs lend a helping paw to eastern Ontario families
items.summary_auto: Two families in eastern Ontario have welcomed some very special four-legged friends into their homes, ones whose job is to help their children with autism.

items.title: Trump said he didn’t want Canadian cars — now one built in Windsor, Ont., is racking up big U.S. awards
items.summary_auto: It was just a few months ago that U.S. President Donald Trump told the world he doesn’t want Canadian cars. But now, it’s a Canadian-built vehicle — a reimagined North American muscle car — that’s been racking up U.S. awards.

items.title: CBSA says 'fragile' IT systems are a 'top government risk' following border outages
items.summary_auto: An internal review of technical outages that caused significant delays at airports and international land borders this fall has exposed critical flaws with the Canada Border Services Agency's IT services.

items.title: 60 Minutes prison segment postponed by CBS briefly viewed in Canada on Global TV
items.summary_auto: A portion of a postponed 60 Minutes segment critical of the Trump administration's deportation policies was temporarily available to watch Monday through a Canadian network's website and app.

items.title: Affordability tops the list for many Canadian holiday shoppers
items.summary_auto: A recent Angus Reid report shows that affordability is a top concern for Canadians this holiday season, causing some shoppers to pull back on gift giving.
